Der Drache weiß durch die Befragung früherer untoter Invasoren, dass diese einer untoten Magierin namens Viantha Cruelhex treu ergeben sind. Claugiyliamatar ist bisher nicht in der Lage, ihre Kristallkugeln zu benutzen, um die Untoten auszuspionieren, und alle Diener, die sie ausgesandt hat, um Viantha zu fangen, sind nicht zurückgekehrt. Sie bittet die Charaktere, Viantha zu fangen oder zu töten und mit dem Gefangenen oder den Überresten der Todesschleuse zum Verhör zurückzukehren (siehe "{@area Finding Viantha|083|x}"). Im Austausch für Viantha erklärt sich Claugiyliamatar bereit, Leilon in Ruhe zu lassen.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Claugiyliamatar hat ein {@item crystal ball}, ein {@item crystal ball of mind reading}, ein {@item crystal ball of telepathy}, und ein {@item crystal ball of true seeing}. Jede ist auf einem 10 Fuß hohen Messingpodest montiert. Der grüne Drache hat ihre {@item Crystal Ball||crystal balls} mit einer mächtigen Verzauberung versehen, um sie vor Diebstahl zu schützen. Wenn ein {@item crystal ball} aus dem Versteck entfernt wird, funktioniert es nicht mehr, bis es wieder in das Versteck zurückgebracht wird.

entries.name: C14. Claugiyliamatar's Hoard
entries: Das erhöhte Plateau, auf dem Claugiyliamatars Schatzkammer liegt, ist 20 Fuß hoch. Am nördlichen und südlichen Rand des Plateaus stehen jeweils zwei Statuen (siehe "{@adventure Statues|SDW|3|Statues. Four statues in this area depict the following figures (see the "{@adventure Lair Features|SDW|3|Lair Features}" Seitenleiste):}" unten). Ein Charakter, der eine erfolgreiche DC 12 Intelligenzprüfung ({@skill Investigation}) ablegt, bemerkt drei leichte Vertiefungen mit einem Durchmesser von 5 Fuß im Boden des Plateaus zwischen den beiden Statuenpaaren. Ein {@spell detect magic}-Zauber offenbart, dass diese Vertiefungen eine Aura der Abjurationsmagie ausstrahlen.

Von der Nordwand bis zur Südwand, zwischen den Statuen und der Schatzkammer, verläuft ein permanenter, raumhoher {@spell wall of force}, der von Claugiyliamatar geschaffen wurde. Der Bereich westlich des {@spell wall of force} ist von eingeschlossenem grünem Gas verdunkelt, aber ein Charakter, der eine erfolgreiche DC 17 Weisheit ({@skill Perception})-Prüfung ablegt, bemerkt einen Haufen Schätze, der sich leicht in dem Gas abzeichnet.
Die Charaktere können die Mauer auf folgende Weise zerstören:

items: Ein Charakter, der den {@spell disintegrate}-Zauber wirkt, zerstört die Mauer.

Wenn die Statuen von Taubenfalkenhand (in {@area area C8|070|x}), Sturmsilberhand (in {@area area C8|070|x}) und Laeral Silberhand (in {@area area C4|06b|x}) neben ihren Schwestern (siehe "{@adventure Statues|SDW|3|Statues. Four statues in this area depict the following figures (see the "{@adventure Lair Features|SDW|3|Lair Features}"-Seitenleiste):}" unten) in die Vertiefungen gestellt werden, wird die Mauer zerstört. Die Mauer wird wieder aufgebaut, wenn eine der Statuen auf dem Plateau entfernt wird. Wenn eine andere Statue als die drei genannten in ein Loch gestellt wird, explodiert die Statue mit gewaltiger Kraft. Jede Kreatur, die sich im Umkreis von 10 Fuß um die Statue befindet, muss einen Schutzwurf von DC 15 auf Geschicklichkeit ablegen und erleidet bei einem misslungenen Schutzwurf 33 ({@dice 6d10}) Wuchtschaden, bei einem erfolgreichen Schutzwurf halb so viel Schaden.

entries: Wird die Wand zerstört, dehnt sich das dahinter befindliche Gas sofort aus und füllt den gesamten Bereich C13 und C14. Eine Kreatur, die das Gas betritt oder ihren Zug darin beginnt, muss einen Konstitutionsschutzwurf von DC 22 machen und erleidet bei einem misslungenen Schutz 77 ({@dice 22d6}) Giftschaden, bei einem erfolgreichen Schutz halb so viel. Kreaturen und Objekte in dem Gas sind leicht verdunkelt. Das Gas bleibt 24 Stunden lang erhalten. Ein mäßiger Wind (mindestens 10 Meilen pro Stunde) vertreibt das Gas nach 4 Stunden. Ein starker Wind (mindestens 20 Meilen pro Stunde) zerstreut es nach 1 Stunde.

entries.name: Statues
entries: Vier Statuen in diesem Bereich stellen die folgenden Figuren dar (siehe die Seitenleiste "{@area Lair Features|057|x}"):

{@b Anastra Syluné Silverhand} ist ein Mensch, der ein einfaches Kleid trägt und zwei Hälften eines zerbrochenen Stabes bei sich hat. Sie starb im Kampf gegen drei Drachen und war eine der Sieben Schwestern, die von Mystra ausgewählt wurden.

{@b Lady Alustriel Silverhand} ist ein Mensch, der ein langes, wallendes Gewand trägt und einen Stab mit einem Einhornkopf hat. Sie diente viele Jahre lang als Anführerin von Silbermond und ist eine der Sieben Schwestern, die von Mystra auserwählt wurden.

{@b Alassra Shentrantra Silverhand}, auch Simbul genannt, ist ein Mensch mit langem, wildem Haar und fließenden Gewändern. Sie war die Königin von Aglarond und eine der Sieben Schwestern, die von Mystra ausgewählt wurden.
{@b Qilué Veladorn} ist eine Drow, die elegante Gewänder trägt und deren Haare ihr bis zu den Knöcheln reichen. Sie war eine der Sieben Schwestern, die von Mystra ausgewählt wurden.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Claugiyliamatars Schatztruhe enthält einen {@item +2 war pick}, einen {@item wand of magic detection}, einen {@item spell scroll} von {@spell speak with dead}, sieben Smaragde im Wert von je 1.000 gp, 1.339 pp und 14.235 gp. Wenn die Charaktere den Schatz des Drachen stehlen, während sie noch lebt, beginnt sie die Jagd auf sie, sobald sie dazu in der Lage ist.

entries.name: Finding Viantha
entries: Nachdem sie mit Claugiyliamatar in ihrem Versteck gesprochen haben, wollen die Charaktere wahrscheinlich Viantha Cruelhex im Kryptgardenwald finden. Jeden Tag, an dem die Charaktere den Wald durchsuchen, sollen sie einen Charakter wählen, der als Führer fungiert. Am Ende eines jeden Tages macht der Führer eine DC 15 Weisheitsprüfung ({@skill Survival}). Bei einem erfolgreichen Check finden die Charaktere Viantha (siehe "{@area Viantha Found|085|x}"). Bei einem Fehlschlag der Probe von 4 oder weniger kommen die Charaktere in die Nähe von Untoten (siehe "Begegnung mit Untoten"). Bei einem Fehlschlag des Checks von 5 oder mehr finden die Charaktere nichts.

entries.name: Undead Encounter
entries: Die Charaktere treffen auf zufällige Untote aus der Tabelle Untote Begegnungen. Die Untoten laufen auf ihrem Weg zu Claugiyliamatars Versteck im Wald Amok und kämpfen mit den Charakteren bis zum Tod. Die Untoten sind Viantha gegenüber loyal und führen die Charaktere nicht in den Todesturm, es sei denn, sie werden magisch dazu gezwungen, dies zu tun.

entries.caption: Undead Encounters
rows: Die Charaktere treffen auf einen {@creature ghast} plus zwei zusätzliche Ghasts für jedes Mitglied der Gruppe, ausgenommen Handlanger.
Die Charaktere treffen auf einen {@creature ogre zombie} plus zwei zusätzliche Oger-Zombies für jedes Mitglied der Gruppe, ohne Sidekicks.
Die Charaktere treffen auf einen {@creature wight} plus einen zusätzlichen Wicht für jedes Mitglied der Gruppe, ohne Handlanger.
Die Charaktere treffen auf einen {@creature wraith} plus einen zusätzlichen Wraith pro zwei Mitglieder der Gruppe (abgerundet), ausgenommen Handlanger.

entries.name: Viantha Found
entries: Wenn die Charaktere Viantha finden, lesen Sie den folgenden Text laut vor, um die Szene darzustellen:

Ein seltsamer, mystischer Gesang mit einer trockenen, knisternden Stimme und ein übler Geruch kommen von einer kleinen Lichtung vor uns. In der Mitte dieses Bereichs fuchtelt eine Frau in Robe mit grauer, rissiger Haut und roten Lichtpunkten an den Stellen, wo eigentlich ihre Augen sein sollten, mit einem Stab aus Knochen in der Luft herum.

Viantha Cruelhex ist eine {@creature deathlock mastermind|MTF} (siehe {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}), die gerade dabei ist, weitere Untote zu beschwören, um Claugiyliamatar mit einem magischen Ritual zu schikanieren. Bevor die Charaktere angreifen können, beschwört Viantha {@b specters} an ihre Seite. Es gibt einen {@creature specter} für jedes Mitglied der Gruppe, ausgenommen die Handlanger. Viantha und die Gespenster kämpfen, bis sie gefangen genommen oder zerstört werden.

entries.name: Roleplaying Viantha
entries: Wenn die Charaktere Viantha mit Ketten oder Handschellen fesseln, geht sie bereitwillig mit ihnen zu Claugiyliamatars Versteck, sagt aber nichts, es sei denn, sie wird magisch dazu gezwungen. Alles, was die Todeslocke über die Pläne von Ularan Mortus weiß, ist, dass der Nekromant will, dass sie weiterhin die Höhle des Drachen angreift.

entries.name: Return to the Lair
entries: Wenn die Charaktere mit Viantha (oder den Überresten des Todesschlosses) in Claugiyliamatars Höhle zurückkehren, bedankt sich der grüne Drache bei den Charakteren. Leider ist der Geist von Ebondeath in der Nähe und wartet auf diese Gelegenheit. Bevor sie noch etwas sagen kann, macht der Drache eine schreckliche Verwandlung durch, die dadurch vermittelt wird, dass den Spielern der folgende Kastentext laut vorgelesen wird:

Claugiyliamatar fällt zu Boden, und ihr ganzer Körper beginnt heftig zu zittern. Ihr Schwanz schlägt um sich, lässt Stalagmiten zu Staub zerfallen und prallt donnernd gegen die Wände der Höhle. Der Drache hat Schaum vor dem Mund, als ein dunkler, wirbelnder Schatten in die Höhle fliegt und sich in ihre Nasenlöcher schleicht. Dann, so plötzlich wie Claugiyliamatars heftiger Anfall begann, hört er wieder auf.

Nach einer kurzen Pause reißen die Augen des Drachens auf und enthüllen, dass ihre einst grünen Augenlider schwarze, lichtlose Gruben sind. "Ich, Chardansearavitriol der Ebondeath, bin zurückgekehrt! Gepriesen sei Myrkul!"

Nachdem Chardansearavitriol von Claugiyliamatars Körper Besitz ergriffen hat, ist der Drache zunächst etwas desorientiert, während er sich an die neue Form gewöhnt. Anstatt in einem solchen Zustand zu kämpfen, flieht Chardansearavitriol aus der Höhle und kehrt nach Ularan Mortus in die Höhle der Toten zurück.

Wenn der Drache den Ort verlässt, dringen ein {@creature sword wraith commander|MTF} (siehe {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) und ein {@creature sword wraith warrior|MTF} (siehe {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) pro zwei Gruppenmitglieder (abgerundet) in den Unterschlupf ein, Kumpane nicht mitgerechnet. Die Schwertgespenster sind Ularan Mortus treu ergeben und greifen die Charaktere an, wobei sie bis zum Tod kämpfen.

data.name: Death Knight-Dreadnaught
entries: "Der Todesritter-Dreadnaught" ist für Charaktere der Stufe 9 ausgelegt, aber auch Charaktere der Stufe 10 werden Teile des Quests als Herausforderung empfinden.

entries.name: Location Overview
entries: Der furchtbare Kultist Ularan Mortus brachte seine Gefolgsleute in einer verfluchten Galeone, die mit der Seele eines Todesritters ausgestattet war, über das Meer. Südlich von Niewinter wurde das Schiff von einem lokalen Kult des Sturmgottes Talos entdeckt, der den Strahl eines magischen Leuchtturms auf das Schiff richtete, um es auf die Felsen zu locken. Als dieser Zauber fehlschlug, schickten die Kultisten ihren Meister, Fheralai Stormsworn, um das Schiff zu kapern. Nach einer schrecklichen Seeschlacht war Ularan Mortus gezwungen, über Bord zu springen und an die Küste zu fliehen.

Da Fheralai den Dreadnought nicht mehr steuern konnte, stürzte er auf die Felsen. Nachdem es gestrandet war, sprach sie mit der düsteren Seele des Schiffes und heckte einen Plan aus, um sie zu besänftigen. Der Geist, der das Schiff bewohnte, stammte aus der verlorenen Stadt Anauria, einem Reich, das vor langer Zeit von der Ausbreitung der Anauroch-Wüste verschluckt wurde. Als Fheralai erfuhr, dass er sich nach seiner alten Heimat sehnte, entführte er den örtlichen Barden Tarbin Tul und zwang ihn, das Schiff mit Liedern aus seiner verlorenen Heimat zu erfreuen. Die List funktionierte. Solange Tarbin regelmäßig für das Schiff singt, ist die Seele des Schiffes bereit, Fheralais Befehle zu befolgen. Seitdem hält die Sturmherrin den Dreadnaught auf den Felsen als Vorposten für ihre bevorstehende Invasion der Schwertküste.

entries.name: Quest Goals
entries: Um das Todesritter-Dreadnaught-Quest abzuschließen (siehe "{@area The Quest Board|025|x}"), müssen die Abenteurer Tarbin Tul aus dem Laderaum des Dreadnaught retten oder ihn anderweitig davon abhalten, auf dem Schiff zu singen. Wenn sie dies tun, wird der Dreadnaught von den Felsen abgetrieben und kehrt ins Meer zurück.

entries.name: Travel to the Ship
entries: Der Dreadnaught liegt etwa zwanzig Meilen nördlich der Stadt Leilon in der Nähe eines alten Leuchtturms, des Turms der Stürme, auf einem Felsen (weitere Informationen zu diesem Ort finden Sie unter {@adventure Dragon of Icespire Peak|DIP}). Wenn die Charaktere die Stadt am Morgen zu Fuß verlassen, können sie das Schiff ein oder zwei Stunden vor Einbruch der Nacht erreichen. Die windgepeitschte Küste dieser Region ist gesäumt von schroffen Granitklippen und Stapeln erodierten Gesteins.

entries.name: Arrival
entries: Wenn sich die Personen dem Schiff nähern, lesen Sie den folgenden Text im Kasten laut vor:

Ein gepanzerter Dreadnought aus Metall und Knochen ruht auf einem Felsvorsprung in der Bucht. Flammen züngeln aus einem an seinem Hauptmast befestigten Kohlenbecken, und seine zerlumpten Segel sind aus abgenutztem Leder genäht. Barbarische Halb-Orks patrouillieren auf den Decks und halten sich bereit, ihre tödlichen Belagerungswaffen einzusetzen. Ein Riesenskelett, das eine Hellebarde umklammert, ist an seinem Bug festgebunden. Mehr als ein Dutzend Zombies sind auf Pfählen aufgespießt, die in den Felsen um das Schiff herum stecken.

Die erste Herausforderung für die Gruppe ist es, den Dreadnaught auszukundschaften oder unbemerkt an Bord zu kommen. Charaktere, die versuchen, sich an das Schiff heranzuschleichen, müssen eine DC 15 Gruppenprobe auf Geschicklichkeit ({@skill Stealth}) bestehen, wobei sie einen Vorteil haben, wenn sie diese Aufgabe bei Nacht versuchen. Bei einem Fehlschlag werden sie von den Kultisten auf dem Deck entdeckt und eröffnen das Feuer mit den an ihrem Schiff montierten Belagerungswaffen (siehe {@adventure areas {@dice D3}|SDW|4|D3. Hauptdeck}-{@adventure {@dice D5}|SDW|4|D5. Vorschiff} und {@adventure {@dice D7}|SDW|4|D7. Poop Deck}). Die Figuren sind 200 Fuß vom Schiff entfernt, wenn sie bei Tag entdeckt werden, oder 100 Fuß, wenn sie bei Nacht entdeckt werden.

entries.name: Staked Zombies
entries: Zwanzig {@creature Zombie||zombies} sind auf Pfählen aufgespießt, die in die Felsen um den Dreadnaught getrieben wurden. Diese Untoten wurden von Ularan Mortus hierher geschickt, um sein Schiff zurückzuerobern, und wurden von Fheralai als Warnung aufgespießt. Jeder Zombie ist mit einer ungewöhnlichen Menge an getrocknetem Vogelkot besprenkelt. Charaktere, die bereits die Ruinen von Iniarvs Turm besucht haben, erkennen sie als von dort stammend (siehe "{@adventure Iniarv's Tower|SDW|5}"). Die Zombies winden sich und stöhnen auf ihren Pfählen, können sich aber nicht bewegen, es sei denn, sie werden niedergeschlagen. Wenn sie befreit werden, greifen sie die nächstgelegenen Lebewesen an.

entries.name: Where is Fheralai Stormsworn?
entries: Dieser Meister des Talos-Kultes befindet sich an Bord des Dreadnoughts, als die Charaktere eintreffen. Du kannst sie überall auf dem Schiff platzieren oder sie zwischen verschiedenen Orten hin- und herbewegen lassen. Wenn sie erfährt, dass Eindringlinge anwesend sind, bewegt sie sich, um sie abzufangen. Lies den folgenden Text laut vor, wenn die Charaktere auf sie treffen:

Ein hochgewachsener weiblicher Halb-Ork tritt ins Blickfeld. Ihre Muskeln sind wie eiserne Bänder und ihr Gesicht ist zu einem bestialischen Fratzengesicht erstarrt. Unter ihrer Kapuze aus Wildschweinfell sieht man Augen, in denen Blitze zucken.
"Das ist jetzt mein Schiff", knurrt sie. "Und ich habe vor, es zu behalten!"

Fheralai ist ein fanatischer junger Halb-Ork {@creature war priest|VGM} (siehe {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}). Sie ist einer der Hauptbösewichte der Geschichte und wird in {@adventure Divine Contention|DC}, dem Abschluss dieser Abenteuertrilogie, zurückkehren. Wenn ein Angriff Fheralai auf weniger als die Hälfte ihrer maximalen Trefferpunkte bringt oder sie sich unterlegen fühlt, versucht sie, das Schiff zu verlassen und in Sicherheit zu fliehen. Macht euch keine Sorgen, wenn Fheralai hier stirbt oder gefangen genommen wird, denn ihre Kultisten nutzen göttliche Intervention, um sie später in der Kampagne zurückzuholen!

entries.name: Death Knight's Soul
entries: Die Seele des Todesritters Emberlost ist in den Knochen des Dreadnoughts gebunden. Als empfindungsfähige, untote Kreatur kann Emberlost durch die skelettierte Galionsfigur ({@adventure area {@dice D2}|SDW|4|D2. Skelettierte Galionsfigur}), seinen eigenen Leichnam unter Deck ({@adventure area {@dice D17}|SDW|4|D17. Seele des Todesritters}) oder die Höllenfeuerkugel am Hauptmast ({@adventure area {@dice D4}|SDW|4|D4. Höllenfeuerkugel}) sehen und sprechen. Der Todesritter hat einen Weisheitsmodifikator ({@skill Perception}) von +3 und eine passive Weisheit ({@skill Perception}) von 13.

Der Todesritter dient nur Kreaturen, denen er gehorchen will. Fheralai Stormsworn besänftigte ihn, indem er einen entführten Barden benutzte, um ihm Lieder aus seiner Heimat vorzusingen. Wenn der Barde gegen Emberlosts Willen aufhört zu singen oder vom Schiff entfernt wird, stößt sich der Todesritter wütend von den Felsen ab und zieht sich aufs Meer zurück. Es liegt in deinem Ermessen, die verfolgte Seele des Todesritters mit anderen Mitteln zu gewinnen (siehe {@adventure area {@dice D17}|SDW|4|D17. Die Seele des Todesritters} für weitere Informationen über diese verfluchte Kreatur).

entries.name: Dreadnaught Features
entries: Der Todesritter-Dreadnaught ist eine Galeone aus humanoiden Knochen, die durch Eisenplatten und nekromantische Magie zusammengehalten werden.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Die unteren Decks des Schiffes sind mit einer Deckenhöhe von gerade einmal einem Meter sehr beengt. Lebewesen, die größer als diese Höhe sind, müssen sich bücken, um herumzukommen.

entries.name: Light
entries: Die unteren Decks werden von Öllampen beleuchtet, die mit unheimlichen grünen Flammen brennen. Sie verbreiten ein schummriges Licht im Inneren des Schiffes und verursachen einen Nachteil bei Weisheitsproben ({@skill Perception}), die sich auf die Sicht verlassen.

entries.name: Unholy Presence
entries: Der Dreadnaught ist mit der verfluchten Seele eines Todesritters beseelt. Alle untoten Kreaturen an Bord des Schiffes oder im Umkreis von 60 Fuß haben einen Vorteil bei Schutzwürfen gegen Eigenschaften, die Untote verwandeln.

entries.name: Dreadnaught Locations
entries: Die folgenden Orte sind mit der Karte des Todesritter-Dreadnoughts verschlüsselt.

entries.name: D1. Coastal Rocks
entries: The dreadnaught rests on slippery sea rocks that are regularly dashed by waves. These rocks count as {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. During combat, any creature that ends its turn on the rocks must roll a die: on an odd result, a wave smashes into them and they must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or fall {@condition prone}.

entries.name: D2. Skeletal Figurehead
entries: The animated skeleton of a stone giant is lashed to the ship's bow. This {@creature giant skeleton|TftYP} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) cannot move and uses the following attack in place of a scimitar:

entries.name: Halberd
entries: {@atk mw} +8 to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@i Hit}: 21 ({@dice 3d10 + 5}) slashing damage.

The evil spirit of the death knight can see and speak through the skeletal figurehead (see "{@area Death Knight's Soul|094|x}"). If the death knight spots intruders outside the ship, it alerts Fheralai below deck and she moves to confront her new guests (see "{@area Fheralai Stormsworn|092|x}").

entries.name: D3. Main Deck
entries: The main deck contains a set of stairs that descend into the bowels of the ship, a ballista mounted on a rotating platform (see "{@book Siege Equipment|DMG|8|Siege Equipment}" in chapter 8 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}), and a hatch that opens into the ship's stores. The hatch can only be opened by creatures with a combined Strength score of 18 or more.

Two {@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|anchorites of Talos} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) are stationed at the ballista, with an additional {@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|anchorite} present on deck for every two characters in the party, including sidekicks. If combat occurs here, the anchorites on the forecastle and quarterdeck ({@adventure areas {@dice D5}|SDW|4|D5. Forecastle} and {@adventure {@dice D6}|SDW|4|D6. Quarterdeck}) respond immediately.

entries.name: D4. Hellfire Orb
entries: The iron brazier mounted on the mainmast contains an ever-burning orb of flame. The spirit of the death knight can see and talk through this orb, perceiving its surroundings with {@sense darkvision} to a range of 120 feet (see "{@area Death Knight's Soul|094|x}"). Once per day, the death knight can hurl a magical ball of fire that explodes at a point it can see within 240 feet of it. Each creature in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw. The sphere spreads around corners. A creature takes 35 ({@dice 10d6}) fire damage and 35 ({@dice 10d6}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: D5. Forecastle
entries: The front deck of the dreadnaught is fitted with a ballista mounted on a rotating platform. Two {@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|anchorites of Talos} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) are assigned to this weapon. When no threats are present, the cultists take turns daring each other to spit on the skull of the giant skeleton mounted under the bowsprit.

entries.name: D6. Quarterdeck
entries: The ship's wheel is fixed to the quarterdeck. The wheel is the round, iron shield that Emberlost carried in battle. If a creature the death knight doesn't know or like touches the wheel, the intruder must succeed at a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 45 ({@dice 10d8}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much necrotic damage on a successful one. After taking this damage, the creature can safely hold the wheel and steer the ship without taking further damage.

entries.name: D7. Poop Deck
entries: Two rear-facing mangonels (see "{@book Siege Equipment|DMG|8|Siege Equipment}" in chapter 8 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}) are mounted on the poop deck, guarded by two {@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|anchorites of Talos} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}). As these weapons can only fire to the rear of the ship, the anchorites can't use them to target the other decks. If combat ensues below, the anchorites move on foot to engage in melee or hurl {@spell Lightning Bolt||lightning bolts} down on the intruders.

The hatch here opens into a 20-foot-deep shaft leading to the ship's magazine. During naval combat, a bucket and winch are used to haul rocks up from the magazine to load the mangonels. A character can climb down the chain to access the magazine at {@adventure area {@dice D13}|SDW|4|D13. Magazine. }

entries.name: D8. Chart Room
entries: The desk is here is laden with sea charts, old maps of the Sword Coast, and enough instruments to assemble a complete set of navigator's tools. Characters who study the ship's course deduce that it set sail from the distant nation of Estagund four months previously. The old maps show the locations of dozens of long-lost barrows along the Sword Coast, indicating that the sailors came here to unearth something buried. Most of these tombs have already been looted or destroyed, but others could form the basis for your own dungeon-based adventures. Ularan Mortus was hunting for the mausoleum of the black dragon Chardansearavitriol. He took the map showing its location with him before he fled the ship.

entries.name: D9. Storage Lockers
entries: These lockers contain supplies for maintaining the vessel: spare rope, buckets, tubs of grease, and other mundane tools. A character who hides inside a locker gains advantage on any Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to evade the crew.

entries.name: D10. Captain's Cabin
entries: This cabin belonged to Ularan Mortus but has since been claimed by Fheralai Stormsworn. Anyone who searches the cabin and succeeds on a DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check discerns that a new resident recently reclaimed the room.

A leather-bound journal lies open on the floor next to the bed. Characters examining the journal discover clues about the necromancer's plans for the region. Give the players the "{@adventure Necromancer's Journal|SDW|10}" handout from {@adventure appendix C|SDW|10}, the contents of which is reproduced in a sidebar below. A note in the journal indicates that Fheralai may have kidnapped a bard to appease the spirit bound in the ship.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A liquor cabinet contains ten bottles of rare spirits worth 100 gp each. The historical tomes on the bookshelves have a combined value of 800 gp but weigh a total of 250 pounds.

entries.name: Necromancer's Journal
entries: This journal belonged to Ularan Mortus, a high priest of Myrkul, god of death. As a member of the Cult of the Dragon, Ularan Mortus colluded with evil dragons to plot the downfall of the Sword Coast. He hopes to reanimate the soul of Ebondeath, a legendary black dragon, and petition it to steal a magical artifact from the town of Leilon. The journal provides no name or clues about the nature of this artifact, but it seems vital to the high priest's invasion plans.

Ularan Mortus sailed over the ocean onboard an undead galleon imbued with the soul of the death knight named Emberlost. The death knight's homeland, Anauria, once lay in this region, and the high priest fears that Emberlost is becoming obsessed with this bygone realm. At this point in the journal, another hand has made a note in the margin: "Roadhouse? Could bard win him over?"

entries.name: D11. Oar Deck
entries: This gloomy oar deck looks like the belly of a whale, with gargantuan ribs sweeping from the walls to form rowing benches for the undead crew. The deck underfoot is littered with humanoid bones to a depth of 1 foot. Two large, unmanned drums are positioned to the rear of the deck.

If the death knight's soul knows that intruders are onboard, it animates a team of {@creature Minotaur Skeleton||minotaur skeletons} to defend the deck. There is one skeleton present for every member of the party, including sidekicks. The skeletons hide underneath the bones until intruders draw near, and then arise to attack them with surprise. If combat ensues here, Gol Badwind arrives from area {@dice D12} to investigate after two rounds.

entries.name: Skeleton Crew
entries: Once per day when the dreadnaught needs to move, the death knight can animate a rowing crew of fifty {@creature Skeleton||skeletons} from the bones piled here. This occurs at the end of the quest if the players stop Tarbin Tul's singing (see {@adventure area {@dice D17}|SDW|4|D17. Death Knight's Soul}).

entries.name: D12. Badwind's Cabin
entries: This cabin is occupied by Fheralai's second-in-command, Gol Badwind, a grossly fat, grumpy half-orc male {@creature blackguard|VGM}. Badwind is the cultists' quartermaster.If the characters slay him, all anchorites left onboard become {@condition frightened} of them.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Badwind carries an {@item alchemy jug} at his belt, which he swigs from while doing his rounds.

entries.name: D13. Magazine
entries: This chamber holds iron balls, ballista bolts, and rocks for the vessel's siege weaponry. A 20-foot-high shaft ascends from here to the poop deck ({@adventure area D7|SDW|4|D7. Poop Deck}), where a bucket and chain dangles from a winch. A character can climb the chain to ascend to the poop deck.

entries.name: D14. Crew Quarters
entries: String hammocks are strung up here like cobwebs. When they enter this area, the characters hear singing drifting from the cabin at {@adventure {@dice D17}|SDW|4|D17. Death Knight's Soul}. Due to the awkwardness of this space, any Medium or larger creature fighting in here counts as squeezing into a smaller space (see "{@book Creature Size|PHB|9|Creature Size}" in chapter 9 of the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}).

The hammocks are enchanted to attack anyone who enters without the death knight's permission. Each hammock has the statistics of a {@creature rug of smothering} except that it looks like a hammock when using its False Appearance feature. One hammock animates for every member of the party, including sidekicks.

entries.name: D15. Galley
entries: The old crew used this galley to prepare food, which consisted of spartan gruels and dry biscuits. There is nothing else in here but bad recipes.

entries.name: D16. Surgery
entries: The door to this compartment is boarded over with heavy planks of wood. Ularan Mortus was known for constructing obedient servants from the stitched-together bodies of former enemies. After the anchorites discovered that the golems in here were immune to lightning damage, they sealed them inside this chamber and boarded up the door. There is one {@creature flesh golem} inside the compartment for every two members of the party, including sidekicks (rounded down). The golems attack anyone who enters.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: An apothecary's bag inside the surgery contains three {@item Potion of Greater Healing||potions of greater healing}.

entries.name: D17. Death Knight's Soul
entries: The corpse of a knight wearing plate armor slumps on a throne at the rear of this compartment. The ship's bones spill from the knight's chest and are entwined with his body, fusing him to the vessel. This was the death knight Emberlost, and though his corpse (as well as the ship itself, hosts his cursed soul, Emberlost may speak through the corpse and see through its eyes, but can't animate it otherwise.

If questioned, the death knight reveals its yearning for Anauria, its lost homeland. Characters who succeed on a DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check recall some tidbit of ancient Anaurian lore that impresses the death knight. It has no loyalty to Fheralai and gladly betrays her if the characters offer a better deal. The terms of such a deal (and if it's even possible) are left up to you (the DM) and your players.
If anyone touches the corpse or strikes it with a melee weapon attack, Emberlost withdraws his body into the hull, swallowing it in bones.

entries.name: The Bard
entries: Tarbin Tul, a kidnapped male human {@creature bard|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) spends his waking hours singing songs of old Anauria to the death knight to keep it appeased. Tarbin wears an ankle manacle that is chained to a heavy iron ball weighing 50 pounds. He is desperate to escape but terrified of defying Fheralai Stormsworn. If Tarbin is taken from the dreadnaught, the soul of the death knight becomes enraged and it steers the vessel out to sea (see "{@area Death Knight's Soul|094|x}").

entries.name: D18. Stores
entries: The dreadnaught's stores contain mundane supplies for the journey: barrels of salted meat, cords of wood, nails, and cloth.

entries.name: D19. Prisoner Cell
entries: When the bard Tarbin Tul (see {@adventure area {@dice D17}|SDW|4|D17. Death Knight's Soul}) becomes too exhausted to perform, the anchorites lock him in this cold cell to recuperate. The door is magically locked with an {@spell arcane lock} spell and can only be opened by castig either {@spell knock} or {@spell dispel magic}. Unlocking the door alerts the death knight's soul to the presence of intruders inside the vessel.

entries.name: D20. Armory
entries: This armory contains racks of maces, spears, and hammers for use by the ship's crew.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: One of the racks contains a magical {@item +2 mace} called {@item Bonecounter|SDW}. Whenever this weapon is used to destroy an undead creature, a single silver piece appears in the wielder's pocket.

entries.name: D21. Flooded Hold
entries: The hold is unlit and flooded to a depth of 3 feet with dark, briny water.

data.name: Iniarv's Tower
entries: "Iniarv's Tower" is balanced for characters of 10th level, though characters of 9th level can survive this quest if they are cautious and rest between encounters.

entries.name: Location Overview
entries: Iniarv's Tower is a ruined stone keep. Iniarv, a mage who became a lich, first occupied the fortress over eight hundred years ago. When a war between a kingdom of goodly peoples and a horde of goblinoids broke out near the keep, it angered Iniarv. The lich called the ocean forth to destroy both armies, creating the Mere of Dead Men. He has not been seen since the incident.

Over the centuries, various bandits, thieves, orc war bands, and others used the tower as a temporary base while it fell further and further into ruin. The Chimera Crew, a group of bandits, currently occupies the lair. Ularan Mortus pays the criminals to guard a growing horde of undead that the necromancer stores in the towers for an imminent attack on Phandalin. The bandits have also decided to make some gold on the side by raiding caravans headed from and to Leilon.

entries.name: Chimera Crew
entries: The Chimera Crew is a group of bandits founded by Rega Swarn. Orphaned at an early age and raised by brigands, Rega found a baby chimera with no one to look after it. She named the baby Ashbreath and trained it to follow her commands. As the chimera grew, Rega and her monstrosity attacked caravans on the road. Soon their success had Rega running the brigand band, who renamed themselves the Chimera Crew.
If a member of the Chimera Crew is captured, the characters can get the bandit to reveal the following information with a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check:

items: The history of Rega and the Chimera Crew's founding.
The bandits were hired by priests of Myrkul to watch over the undead in Iniarv's Tower's ruins.
They do not know where the priests operate or what the priests plan to do with the undead.

entries.name: Quest Goals
entries: To complete the Iniarv's Tower Quest (see "{@area The Quest Board|025|x}"), the adventurers must kill or drive out the bandits living in the ruins of Iniarv's Tower.

entries.name: Travel to Iniarv's Tower
entries: During the twenty-mile journey from Leilon to Iniarv's Tower, the characters experience the following encounter as they pass by the Mere of Dead Men.

entries.name: Zombie Escape
entries: Set the scene by reading the following boxed text aloud:

Groans fill the air as moaning humanoid figures covered in dried bird droppings sprint toward you on the road. As these beings near, their grayish rotting flesh becomes apparent. A pair of red-faced women in heavy armor run behind the undead crying, "Stop those zombies!"

{@creature Greater Zombie|TftYP|Greater zombies} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) that escaped from Iniarv's Tower by smashing a hole through a tower wall are chased by Chimera Crew members Alevene Windcoat and Niri Bronzecrown, who are chaotic evil human {@creature Veteran||veterans}. There are two greater zombies plus one additional greater zombie for every two members of the party (rounded down), not including sidekicks. The zombies attack the characters, fighting until destroyed.

At first Alevene and Niri help the characters fight the undead, but when only one zombie remains, they turn on the characters as the bandits do not want to leave witnesses. The brigands fight until one falls. At that point the other attempts to flee back to Iniarv's Tower. If the characters capture one of the criminals, they reveal how the zombies escaped the ruins in addition to the information contained in the "{@area Chimera Crew|0b9|x}" sidebar with a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check.

entries.name: Iniarv's Tower Features
entries: The ruins of Iniarv's Tower consist of three towers: one enormous 80-foot-high main tower connected to two smaller 30-foot-high towers by walkways. The towers are surrounded by parapets at the top of the walls that create the keep.

entries.name: Arrow Slits
entries: When using an arrow slit for protection, a creature gains three-quarters cover against outside threats. A Medium or larger creature can't squeeze through an arrow slit, but a Small creature can with a successful DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. Tiny creatures can move through the slits without squeezing.

entries.name: Doors
entries: The doors in Iniarv's Tower are made of stone and have rusty iron hinges.

entries.name: Light
entries: Most of the light in the ruins comes from the sun or moon outside, but the shorter towers have hanging lanterns within which provide bright light.

entries.name: Parapets
entries: Parapets standing 3 feet high run along the outside of the keep's wall walkways ({@area area I1|0c7|x}) and the roof of the main tower ({@area area I6|0d1|x}). When using the parapets for protection, a Medium or smaller creature gains half cover.

entries.name: Walls
entries: Climbing the stone walls of the ruin without equipment requires a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Arrival
entries: As the characters approach the ruins of Iniarv's Tower, read the following boxed text aloud:

Atop an escarpment on the eastern side of the High Road stands a crumbling keep with thirty-foot-high walls supported by a gatehouse, two short towers, and one tall tower more than twice as tall as the keep's walls. There is a large opening in the north wall where the defenses crumbled long ago.

As the characters approach the keep, scouts atop the keep's walls ({@area area I1|0c7|x}) watch for danger. The characters must succeed on a DC 15 group Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check to approach the keep unseen.

A 10-foot-deep ditch that was once a moat runs around the perimeter of the keep. The ditch is {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. A wooden bridge crosses the ditch and leads to the front entrance of the gatehouse ({@area area I3|0c9|x}).

There are three entrances to the keep: the hole in the wall ({@area area I2|0c8|x}), the gatehouse ({@area area I3|0c9|x}), and the rubble-sealed crack in the main tower's first floor ({@area area I5|0cf|x}). The characters do not notice the last entrance unless they move around to that side of the keep.

entries.name: Iniarv's Tower Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to the map of the ruins of Iniarv's Tower.

entries.name: I1. Walls
entries: The walls of the keep stand 30 feet high. Three human Chimera Crew {@creature Scout||scouts} patrol the walls. If the scouts notice the characters approaching the ruins, they alert the Chimera Crew camp ({@area area I4|0cd|x}) then call out to the characters and ask them to state their business. A character convinces the scouts they are allies with a successful DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check, and the scouts allow the characters to enter through the gatehouse ({@area area I3|0c9|x}) then bring them to Rega Swarn in {@area area I7|0d2|x}. If the scouts attack the characters, the rest of the Chimera Crew in areas I4 and I7 join the fray.

entries.name: I2. Pit Trap
entries: The Chimera Crew dug a 10-foot-deep pit trap with a 10-foot-square opening in the ground along the hole in the north wall. The pit is covered by a large tarp anchored on the pit's edge and camouflaged with dirt and debris. A creature with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 14 or higher notices the pit.

Any creature that steps on the tarp falls into the pit and pulls the tarp with it, taking 3 ({@dice 1d6}) bludgeoning damage and landing {@condition prone}. The bottom of the pit contains a {@creature swarm of poisonous snakes}. Climbing the walls of the pit without equipment requires a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: I3. Gatehouse
entries: The stone gatehouse has two stories. The first story is one interior room with a 30-foot-high ceiling. The second story has no roof.

When the characters enter the first story, they immediately smell and see oil on the floor and walls. If set ablaze, the oil burns for 1 minute. While the oil burns, each creature that enters or starts its turn in the first story of the gatehouse takes 11 ({@dice 2d10}) fire damage.

entries.name: Doors and Portcullises
entries: The first story of the gatehouse has two sets of double doors behind iron portcullises. Each portcullis requires a successful DC 18 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check to lift and immediately slams back down when the creature that lifted the portcullis stops holding it. A portcullis has AC 19, 27 hit points, immunity to poison and psychic damage, and a damage threshold of 5.

The gatehouse's front double doors are secured with an iron bar from the inside, and the back-double doors are secured with the same mechanism from the courtyard side. A creature that can reach a bar can lock or unlock the bar as an action. Forcing open a secured set of double doors requires a successful DC 20 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. Each door has AC 19, 27 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

entries.name: Murder Holes
entries: The second story has eight 1-foot-diameter murder holes in the floor that look down into the first story of the gatehouse. When using a murder hole to fight, a creature on the second story gains three-quarters cover against threats on the first story. A Medium or larger creature can't squeeze through a murder hole, but a Small creature can with a successful DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. Tiny creatures can move through the holes without squeezing.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A small iron box in the northeast corner of the second story contains two {@item Alchemist's Fire (flask)|PHB|flasks of alchemist's fire}, which the Chimera Crew can throw down the murder holes to set the oil on the first story ablaze.

entries.name: I4. Courtyard
entries: Most of the Chimera Crew stays in the mud-covered courtyard, which contains their tents. At any given moment, a member of the crew here could be cooking over a small campfire, drinking, eating, planning a raid, playing a game, preparing equipment, resting, or socializing. When the characters arrive, the Chimera Crew in the courtyard consists of three human {@b scouts} and one {@b veteran} for every member of the party, including sidekicks.

If the brigands in the courtyard notice intruders, they immediately attack. If combat breaks out here, members of the Chimera Crew in {@area areas I1|0c7|x} and {@area I7|0d2|x} join the battle. If only two members of the Chimera Crew remain, they attempt to remove the barricade in front of the entrance to area I5 and the chain on the door to {@area area I9|0d7|x} to flood the courtyard with undead to cover their escape.

entries.name: Slippery Mud
entries: When a creature standing in the courtyard is hit by an attack that is a critical hit, the target must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or fall {@condition prone}.

entries.name: I5. Main Tower
entries: The main tower in the keep stands 80 feet tall. As the characters approach the tower, they notice it reeks of rot and animal waste.

Two entrances lead inside the tower: an entrance from the courtyard (area I4) barricaded with old wood furniture and a 3-foot-wide, 5-foot-high crack in the back wall filled with stone rubble. A creature can clear the blockage from either entrance with a successful DC 17 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check made as an action. If an entrance is cleared, the undead inside come out and immediately begin attacking any creatures they notice that are not undead. The Chimera Crew do not open an entrance unless they think it will give them an advantage in combat or they are with a priest of Myrkul who can command the undead.

The bottom floor of the tower contains {@creature Zombie||zombies} and {@creature Ogre Zombie||ogre zombies} covered in bird droppings thanks to the hole in the roof above (area I6). There are two {@creature Zombie||zombies} and one {@creature ogre zombie} for every member of the party, including sidekicks.

entries.name: Collapsed Cellar Entrance
entries: The entrance to the keep's cellar collapsed long ago and requires many days of work to clear. What this cellar might hold (perhaps a secret sanctum where Iniarv hides practicing magic) is up to you.

entries.name: I6. Main Tower Roof
entries: Ten {@creature Swarm of Ravens||swarms of ravens} live on what remains of the main tower's roof. They attack any creature that comes within 30 feet of the roof, fighting until the creature retreats.

If more than 100 pounds of weight are added to the remains of the roof, it collapses. Creatures inside the tower when the roof collapses must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw, taking 28 ({@dice 8d6}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures on top of the roof when it collapses take 28 ({@dice 8d6}) bludgeoning damage from the fall and another 28 ({@dice 8d6}) bludgeoning damage from fallig roof debris.

entries.name: I7. North Guard Tower First Floor
entries: The first floor of the north guard tower has a 30-foot-high ceiling. The floor is covered in straw, which services as a bed for Ashbreath, a {@creature chimera}. Rega Swarn, a chaotic evil human {@creature master thief|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) is feeding the chimera chunks of humanoid flesh, unless they joined a fight in {@area areas I1|0c7|x} or {@area I4|0cd|x}. See the "{@area Chimera Crew|0b9|x}" sidebar for more information about Rega and Ashbreath.

If the characters approach Rega in a nonthreatening manner, she asks why they have come to Iniarv's Tower. If a character claims to be an ally willing to help the Chimera Crew and succeeds on a DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check, Rega asks the characters to stick around and help raid the next caravan that passes. Otherwise she attacks with Ashbreath, fighting to the death. If a fight breaks out here, members of the Chimera Crew in {@area areas I1|0c7|x} and {@area I4|0cd|x} join the fray.

entries.name: Ladder
entries: A ladder leads to a trap door in the ceiling that leads to area I8.

entries.name: Steel Box
entries: A character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 15 or higher spots a locked steel box hidden beneath the straw. Rega has the key to this box, which is trapped with a {@trap poison needle} (see "{@book Sample Traps|DMG|5|Sample Traps}" in chapter 5 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

The box has AC 19, 18 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. The lock can be picked with a successful DC 17 Dexterity check using thieves' tools. The box can be forced open with a successful DC 13 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. The box contains Rega's treasure.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The steel box contains a {@item potion of diminution}, 36 pp, and 1,215 gp.

entries.name: I8. North Guard Tower Second Floor
entries: The second floor of the north guard tower has a 10-foot-high ceiling. This area is stocked with trade goods (see {@book chapter 5|PHB|5|Trade Goods} of the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}) worth a total of 300 gp that were stolen from caravans on the road.

entries.name: I9. South Guard Tower First Floor
entries: The door to this area from {@area area I4|0cd|x} is chained shut from the outside. A creature that can reach the chain can remove it as an action, or force the door open, breaking the chain by making a DC 20 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check as an action.

The Chimera Crew moved the {@creature Greater Zombie|TftYP|greater zombies} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) to this location after they broke through a weakened area of the main tower ({@area area I5|0cf|x}). There is one {@creature greater zombie|TftYP} plus one additional greater zombie for every two members of the party (rounded down), not including sidekicks.

entries.name: I10. South Guard Tower Second Floor
entries: This area has the same features as {@area area I8|0d6|x}.

data.name: Leilon Point
entries: "Leilon Point" is balanced for characters of 9th level, though characters of 10th level will still find parts of the quest challenging.

entries.name: Location Overview
entries: Leilon Point is a small community of farmers and fishers, originally formed centuries ago to supply the town of Leilon with food. When Leilon fell, the village remained, but it has recently increased its production to support the rebuilding of the town.

One tenday ago, a band of sahuagin scouts made Salt Cave beneath Leilion Point their base of operations for performing raids on the farms. Gahza, the sahuagin's high priestess leader, brought the raiders to the cave after they investigated the disappearance of the knight-dreadnaught near the Tower of Storms. Fheralai had turned the nuisance of the sahuagin into an opportunity when she used an illusion to appear as a sapient shark (an animal revered by sahuagin) before Gahza, telling the aquatic priestess to raid the farming community. The sahuagin fell for the ruse and now believe they are doing the work of their goddess, Sekolah.

entries.name: Quest Goals
entries: To complete the Leilon Point Quest (see "{@area The Quest Board|025|x}"), adventurers must kill or drive out the sahuagin in Salt Cave.

entries.name: Arrival at Leilon Point
entries: Leilon Point is ten miles from the town of Leilon. When the characters arrive at Leilon Point, read the following boxed text aloud:

The farms of Leilon Point are deathly quiet and still. Every window in the community of thirteen quaint buildings is shuttered. Many of the village's fields are reduced to blackened ash, and its single street is lined with overturned carts, destroyed sacks of grain, and the rotting, slaughtered carcasses of chickens and pigs.

Though this village on a seaside cliff is mostly farmhouses, four buildings without attached fields stand out. The first, a large cottage, has a sign outside its door that reads, "Head House." Second, a cubic wood building depicts the image of curling waves on its front door. Third is a brick building high up on a hill, its massive windows shuttered tight. The final place of interest is a stone shed with a smashed door at the edge of town, near a path that winds toward the water.
After the latest attack, the people of the Leilon Point have decided to stay shut up in their houses and wait for help.

entries.name: Leilon Point Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to the map of Leilon Point.

entries.name: Farmhouses
entries: The families inside the unlabeled buildings on the map of Leilon Point are farmers, fishers, and their children. No amount of persuasion or intimidation can convince the terrified families to open their doors or speak to the characters.

entries.name: Fishing Supply Hut
entries: Nets, hooks, chains, rope, and other fishing supplies lay destroyed on the floor of this hut near the corpse of an old woman lying face down in a pool of dried blood. Manda Gutterpunch ran this shop that serviced the fishers in the village. A character who searches her body, making a successful DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check finds the tip of a blade made of bone in a fatal wound in Manda's stomach, and with a successful DC 18 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check can tell it is of sahuagin make.

entries.name: Head House
entries: The town's leader, a nervous elderly human named Marciano Belta, occupies the Head House. As the town's headman, Marciano settles disputes and keeps order, a relatively easy job until the sahuagin arrived. Marciano refuses to answer questions shouted through the door unless a character first succeeds on a DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check to gain his trust. Characters who break into his house have disadvantage on all Charisma checks made to interact with Marciano. Once the characters gain Marciano's trust, he shares the following information:

items: A tenday ago, a band of violent shark people appeared out of nowhere on the eastern edge of town and began burning fields and killing animals. The attack stopped almost as soon as it began.

Marciano sent word to Leilon for help after the first attack, but more raids followed. There was one attack each day at a different time from a different direction. With every attack the shark people destroyed more property.
Seven days ago, some of the fishers in the town took weapons and their boats to Salt Cave to see if the raiders were in the caves. The fishers have not returned.
Five days ago, Marciano ordered everyone in Leilon Point to remain inside until further notice and wait for help to come from Leilon.

entries: Marciano describes the raiders as green-scaled monsters with finned heads. After sharing this information with the characters, he begs them to find and drive off the aquatic raiders.

entries.name: Huer's Hut
entries: If the characters inspect the huer's hut they find the door to the one-room home is unlocked. Inside they find a bed, a fireplace, a table set with cook's utensils and a spyglass, a chair, a large handbell, and a bookcase full of novels about adventure. This hut belongs to Callana Devro, who was killed in Salt Cave. A character who searches the bed finds a book beneath the pillow called {@i Sea Devils}, which contains all the information about {@creature sahuagin} found in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}.
A huer watches the sea for shoals from a cliff and calls out to ships below in danger of beaching.

entries.name: Umberlee Shrine
entries: The door to the one-room shrine of Umberlee, goddess of the sea, is unlocked. Characters who enter find the corpse of an elf priestess, Nava Wavecrash, lying in a pool of her own blood next to a stone altar. Characters who search Nava's body find a {@item potion of water breathing}.

entries.name: Wait It Out
entries: The characters might decide to wait for the sahuagin to exit the cave to raid the town rather than assault the cave. If they take this course of action, roll a {@dice d10}. The result equals the number of hours the characters wait. At the end of this time, all the sahuagin and the giant shark skeleton exit the cave and attack.

entries.name: Arrival at Salt Cave
entries: If the characters talk to Marciano Belta at the head house, they learn that the sahuagin utilize several entrances to Salt Cave to attack the town. The characters can find the southernmost entrance, which is not hidden, by simply walking down the path to from the village to the cave. The cave's other two entrances can be found by tracking the sahuagin with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check.
If the characters come to the cave's southernmost entrance, they notice three abandoned rowboats left by the fishers that died in the cave.

entries.name: Salt Cave Features
entries: Salt Cave is a natural cave system.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: The ceilings throughout the cave are 20 feet high.

entries.name: Light
entries: Unless otherwise noted in an area's description, there are no light sources in the cave except for those the characters bring with them.

entries.name: Walls
entries: Climbing the rough stone walls of the cave without equipment requires a successful DC 13 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Salt Cave Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to the map of Salt Cave. Sahuagin in the cave attack any characters they notice, fighting to the death.

entries.name: S1. Head Hall
entries: The severed heads of six humans on spears line the south wall of this cavern. The bodies of these humans are thrown at the back of the cave, covering a patch of floor where the {@spell glyph of warding} spell was cast. If the bodies are moved, the glyph is triggered, and it erupts with magical thunder in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on it. Each creature in the area must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@dice 5d8}) thunder damage on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage on a successful one. The glyph disappears after it is triggered.
If the glyph is triggered, the sahuagin in area S2 investigate.

entries.name: S2. Clam Cavern
entries: A glowing clam made of coral stands atop a 10-foot-high cliff, filling this chamber with bright green light. The clam was gifted to Gahza when she became a high priestess. If she dies, the clam stops shedding light. Sahuagin in the clam's light have advantage on attack rolls.
At the center of the chamber a 10-foot-deep pool is filled with seawater and a swarm of hungry baby sharks that use the statistics of a {@creature swarm of quippers}.

Gahza, a {@creature sahuagin high priestess|GoS} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}), stands next to the clam, leading a group of swimming {@creature Sahuagin Blademaster|GoS|sahuagin blademasters} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) in wild prayer to Sekolah. There is one blademaster plus one additional blademaster per two members of the party (rounded down), not including sidekicks.

entries.name: S3. Training Cavern
entries: A {@creature sahuagin blademaster|GoS} (see {@adventure appendix A|SDW|8}) trains a group of {@creature sahuagin} to fight on the bottom level of this chamber. There are two sahuagin for every member of the party, not including sidekicks.

A boulder atop the 10-foot-high platform in this room mostly covers a small hole where Gahza hides her treasure. A character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 16 or higher notices the edges of the hole around one side of the boulder. A character can move the boulder to get to the treasure beneath with a successful DC 13 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The hole beneath the rock contains a black pearl worth 500 gp, 1,321 sp, and 426 gp.

entries.name: S4. Ritual Cavern
entries: A circle of sahuagin symbols are drawn in blood around the bones of a giant shark. Several {@creature Sahuagin Priestess||sahuagin priestesses} chant around the bones, which come to life as a {@creature giant shark skeleton|SDW} controlled by the priestesses. There is one sahuagin priestess plus one additional priestess for every member of the party, not including sidekicks.
The giant shark skeleton has the statistics of a {@creature giant shark} with the following changes:

items: The shark is undead and doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.
The shark is vulnerable to bludgeoning damage, immune to poison damage and the {@condition poisoned} condition, and cannot gain levels of {@condition exhaustion}.
The shark has had skeletal feet attached by some demented necromancer and gains a walking speed of 20 feet.

data.name: Ending the Adventure
entries: The adventure can end one of several ways. Ideally, it concludes with the adventurers witnessing Claugiyliamatar's body becoming possessed by Chardansearavitriol's spirit and the completion of all the The Quest Board. By then the characters should be 11th level. Give the players a chance to wrap up loose ends before declaring the adventure over. For example, the characters might need to return to Leilon to collect an outstanding reward or notify the town council of Claugiyliamatar's possession. The story doesn't have to stop there. If you play {@adventure Divine Contention|DC}, the next adventure in the Beyond Dragon of Icespire Peak series, the characters will have final showdowns with the cults of Myrkul and Talos that decide the ultimate fate of Leilon.

If the worst happens and the characters die, their adventure is also over. You can let the players roll up new characters and pick up where the last ones left off, or you can also start the adventure over with new characters, tweaking quests as you see fit to surprise your players who might otherwise be familiar with them.

You might expand the adventure by inventing new quests and new locations. Several other D&D adventures, {@adventure Out of the Abyss|OotA}, {@adventure Princes of the Apocalypse|PotA}, {@adventure Rise of Tiamat|RoT}, and {@adventure Waterdeep: Dungeon of the Mad Mage|WDMM}, take place in the Forgotten Realms and include challenges for characters of 11th and higher levels.

data.name: Appendix B: Sidekicks
entries: This appendix presents the game statistics for sidekicks, of which there are three types:

items: {@b Expert}, an agile and exceedingly helpful jack of all trades
{@b Spellcaster}, a magic-user who can cast spells to harm your foes or heal you and your friends
{@b Warrior}, a martial companion who specializes in striking your foes or defending you and your allies

entries: You can tell the players which type of sidekick to use or let the players choose. It's up to you and the players to decide who controls the sidekick in play.
If the characters have already played through {@adventure Storm Lord's Wrath|SLW}, they can use the same sidekicks from that adventure. This appendix can also help you level up those sidekicks.

entries.name: Donnabella Fiasco
entries: {@i Human Spellcaster}
Donnabella is a young magic-user who wears a papier-mâché unicorn mask because it makes her feel more magical.
Use the {@creature Spellcaster|ESK} sidekick stat block to represent her.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "I'd rather talk to a book than most people."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "We all have a little magic in us. The trick is finding it and bringing it forth."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I want to join a prestigious wizards' academy one day. I just hope they accept unicorns!"

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I can't keep a secret to save my life—or anyone else's."

entries.name: Galandro Luna
entries: {@i Human Expert}
Galandro's most treasured possession is a fiddle that he tunes and plucks constantly.
Use the {@creature Expert|ESK} sidekick stat block to represent him.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "I love a good insult, even one directed at me."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "I like seeing the smiles on people's faces when I perform. That plus their adoration is all that matters."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "My fiddle was gifted to me by a good friend. I cherish it above all other things."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I'll do anything to win fame and renown."

entries.name: Inverna Nightbreeze
entries: {@i Moon Elf Warrior}
Inverna has a scar on her cheek where she was grazed by an orc's javelin. She is cautious by nature and suspicious of strangers.
Use the {@creature Warrior|ESK} sidekick stat block to represent her.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "I choose my words very carefully. Sarcasm, I'm told, is my sharpest weapon."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "All people deserve to be treated with dignity, regardless of their station. Of course, orcs aren't people."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "Orcs are a blight on the land. For the sake of the natural and civilized worlds, I kill them on sight."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I can't admit when I'm wrong."

entries.name: Nib Addlespur
entries: {@i Lightfoot Halfling Spellcaster}
Nib is a happy-go-lucky gambler who keeps a deck of Three-Dragon Ante cards in her vest pocket. She also has a goldfinch named Lil.
Use the {@creature Spellcaster|ESK} sidekick stat block to represent her.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "I can't resist a sure bet or a friendly wager."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "The more complicated the scheme, the better."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I love birds and will do what I can to look after them."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "Deep water terrifies me. I would rather be swallowed by a dragon than get in a boat or go for a swim."

entries.name: Pickled Pete
entries: {@i Human Expert}
Pete likes ale and tends to function better while tipsy. At his best, he's quite the handyman and comes up with all sorts of crazy ways to get things done.
Use the {@creature Expert|ESK} sidekick stat block to represent him.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "My friends know they can rely on me, no matter what."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "I like coming up with new ways to do things. What problem can't be solved with a little ingenuity?"

entries.name: Bond
entries: "A full flask of wine is worth ten pockets full of gold."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "All this drinking is bad for my memory. Seriously, I can't remember my last name."

entries.name: Quinn Hightopple
entries: {@i Lightfoot Halfling Warrior}
Quinn is a happy little scrapper who likes to punch people in the groin.
Use the {@creature Warrior|ESK} sidekick stat block to represent him.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "Nice set of teeth you got there. Be a shame if something bad happened to 'em."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "No challenge is too big to overcome. As Papa Bartho always says, the bigger they are, the harder they fall."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "Nothing's more important than friendship. That's why I'll never leave a friend behind."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I can't resist punching tall folk in the groin. I call it the Halfling Hello."

entries.name: Ruby Hammerwhacker
entries: {@i Shield Dwarf Warrior}
Ruby lacks the customary dwarven stoicism and greets every day with a warm smile and a renewed sense of optimism.
Use the {@creature Warrior|ESK} sidekick stat block to represent her.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "Nothing can shake my optimistic attitude."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "We should all seek the betterment of ourselves. There's always room for improvement."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I fight for those who cannot fight for themselves"

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "Tell me I can't do something, and I must prove you wrong."

entries.name: Shanjan Kwan
entries: {@i Human Spellcaster}
Kwan died and was raised from the dead as an infant, whereupon a tiny black glyph—the symbol of necromancy—appeared on his forehead.
Use the {@creature Spellcaster|ESK} sidekick stat block to represent him.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "I've cheated death once. I can do it again."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "Great beauty can hide great ugliness. The reverse is also true."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I've been searching my whole life for the answer to a simple question: Am I a god?"

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "I don't like mysteries. Unraveling them keeps me up at night."

entries.name: Talon Thornwild
entries: {@i Human Expert}
Talon loves gold and adventure, and dreams of being a famous gold prospector.
Use the {@creature Expert|ESK} sidekick stat block to represent them.

entries.name: Personality
entries: "Yes, I eat like a pig and have bad manners, but those are my only flaws, I swear. I'm darn near perfect otherwise."

entries.name: Ideal
entries: "The low are lifted up, and the high and mighty are brought down. Change is the nature of things."

entries.name: Bond
entries: "I like gold. I like its color, its texture, its majestic gleam."

entries.name: Flaw
entries: "It's not stealing if I need it more than someone else."

entries.name: Sidekick Stat Blocks
entries: The following stat blocks work with any character race. If you and the DM agree, you may enhance your sidekick with the appropriate racial traits presented in {@book chapter 2|PHB|2|Racial Traits} of the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}.

entries.name: Proficiencies
entries: A sidekick is proficient with any armor, weapons, and tools included in its stat block. In addition, {@b experts} are proficient with simple weapons, rapiers, shortswords, and light armor; {@b spellcasters} are proficient with simple weapons and light armor; and {@b warriors} are proficient with simple and martial weapons, shields, and all armor.

entries.name: Sidekick Level
entries: In this adventure a sidekick starts as a 9th-level character. As the characters and sidekick adventure together, the sidekick gains experience points and reaches new levels the same way a player character does, using the rules in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}.
When a sidekick gains a level, look at the sidekick's table below, and consult the new level's row, which shows the sidekick's new hit point maximum and features.

rows.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: The expert's Dex. score increases by 2, raising the modifier by 1, so increase the following numbers by 1: the Dex. saving throw bonus; the Armor Class; the {@skill Acrobatics}, {@skill Sleight of Hand}, and {@skill Stealth} bonuses; and the bonuses to hit and damage of the expert's weapon attacks.

rows.name: Reliable Talent
entries: Whenever the expert makes an ability check that includes its whole proficiency bonus, it can treat a {@dice d20} roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

rows.name: Empowered Spells
entries: Choose one {@book school of magic|PHB|10|The Schools of Magic}. Whenever the spellcaster casts a spell of that school by expending a spell slot, the spellcaster can add its spellcasting ability modifier to the spell's damage roll or healing roll, if any. Spellcasting. The spellcaster learns another cantrip: {@spell spare the dying} (healer) or {@spell Shocking Grasp||shocking grasp} (mage). The caster also gains one 5th‐level spell slot and learns one new 5th‐level spell: {@spell mass cure wounds} (healer) or {@spell hold monster} (mage).

rows.name: Spellcasting
entries: The spellcaster gains one 6th‐level spell slot and learns one new 6th‐level spell: {@spell heal} (healer) or {@spell chain lightning} (mage).

rows.name: Improved Defense
entries: The warrior's AC increases by 1.

rows.name: Extra Attack
entries: The warrior can attack three times, instead of once, whenever it takes the attack action on its turn.

data.name: Appendix C: Necromancer's Journal
entries: How does one woo a legendary dragon? Great treasure for certain. I wonder how Ebondeath might feel about the prospect of immortality.

Once my collegues in {@i cultus draconis} have prepared the proper rituals, we can take command of the wyrm and add its strength to our own. Then I, Ularan Mortus will command their respect as well as the fears of that pathetic alliance of lords.

If we can accomplish this, certainly no task shall be too great for a true devotee of the lord of bones. At that point, taking possession of the {@i artefact} from that ridiculous little berg of Leilon should be child's play.

The dreadnaught grows restless. Emberlost seeks hopelessly to be reunited with his fallen homeland of Anauria. How does one ease the obsessive behaviors of {@i eques mortem}? Particularly in its current state?
{@i [A note in the margin, written in a different hand]}
{@b Roadhouse? Could bard win him over}?
